discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct

comments.content:
Only E is OK
Wrong A. Online redefinition can be done at table or cluster level
Wrong B. Specify all columns in col_mapping parameter to move whole table
Wrong C. db_securefile to NEVER prevents use securefile, all options like compress/dedup will thrown exception
Wrong D. NOLOGGING storage parameter is permitted but is recommended? Nologging is faster but not safe. Maybe this quote is key for this question:

Maybe "NOLOGGING setting is converted internally to FILESYSTEM_LIKE_LOGGING. FILESYSTEM_LIKE_LOGGING ensures that data is completely recoverable after a server failure."

D and E are correct. Based on Oracle documentation pasted by @orakell: 
D: To prevent generation of redo space during migration make sure that you specify the NOLOGGING storage parameter for the new SecureFiles LOB column(s). You can turn LOGGING on once your migration is complete.
E: Online redefinition is the only recommended method for migration of BasicFiles LOBs to SecureFiles LOBs. It can be done at the table or partition level.

discussion.content: Answers are D and E, straight from the Oracle doc. https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/appdev.112/e18294/adlob_smart.htm#ADLOB45231

choices.C: Set the database initialization parameter db_securefile to NEVER.
choices.B: Specify only BasicFiles LOB and SecureFiles LOB column names in parameter col_mapping of DBMS_REDEFINITION.START_REDEF_TABLE.
choices.E: Online redefinition is the recommended method for migration of BasicFile LOBs to Secure LOBs.
choices.D: During migration, specify the NOLOGGING storage parameter for any new SecureFiles LOB columns.
choices.A: Online redefinition can be done only at the table level.

questions.question_text: Which two are correct when migrating BasicFile LOBs to SecureFile LOBs by DBMS_REDEFINITION?

choices.D: CREATE FUNCTION get_hire_date (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN VARCHAR2 RESULT_CACHE RELIES_ON (employees) AUTHID CURRENT_USER IS date_hired DATE;
choices.C: CREATE FUNCTION get_hire_date (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN VARCHAR2 RESULT_CACHE AUTHID DEFINER IS date_hired DATE;
choices.B: CREATE FUNCTION get_hire_date (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN VARCHAR2 RESULT_CACHE AUTHID CURRENT_USER IS date_hired DATE;
choices.E: CREATE FUNCTION get_hire_date (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN VARCHAR2 AUTHID DEFINER IS
choices.A: CREATE FUNCTION get_hire_date (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN VARCHAR2 RESULT_CACHE RELIES_ON (departments) AUTHID CURRENT_USER IS date_hired DATE;

discussion.content:
PLS-00999 & invoker-rights is true but in 11g. in 12c this restriction dissapear.
Correct answer: B, D (RELIES_ON is deprecated in 12c, but we can still use it)

Selected Answer: BD
BD is correct - CURRENT_USER and it makes no sense to rely on a table that's not relevant

comments.content:
Sorry, I was wrong. it was in ora11. 
In ora 12 AUTHID CURRENT_USER + RESULT_CACHE is OK.
According to https://education.oracle.com/oracle-database-advanced-pl-sql/pexam_1Z0-148, Exam has been validated against Oracle Database 12c.
 Correct answer is B,D.

discussion.content:
https://blogs.oracle.com/oraclemagazine/plsql-enhancements
AUTHID CURRENT_USER + RESULT_CACHE will lead to err: 
RESULT_CACHE is 
disallowed on subprograms in 
Invoker-Rights modules

comments.content: C and E both user definer's rights, not invoker's rights.

discussion.content:
E will not fire until you put "date_hired date;" at the end of statement

the right answer are C and E

 D - will prompt an Error(1,10): PLS-00999: implementation restriction (may be temporary) RESULT_CACHE is disallowed on subprograms in Invoker-Rights modules

choices.D: When the RESULT_CACHE_MODE parameter is set to FORCE.
choices.B: When a session executes an insert, update, or delete statement on a table or view that is queried by the result-cached function
choices.A: When the memory allocated to the server result cache is increased using the RESULT_CACHE_MAX_SIZE initialization parameter
choices.C: When a session on this database instance invokes the function with the same parameter values
choices.E: When a new session is opened to invoke the function which is already cached

questions.question_text: In which situation will cached results become invalid?

comments.content: Agree, B is the only correct answer.

discussion.content: The only correct answer here is B according to that link. "Cached query results become invalid when data in the database object(s) being accessed by the query is (are) modified."

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer, there is no second correct answer

Selected Answer: B
B is actually correct

B: is correct!! 
The UDF pragma tells the compiler that the PL/SQL unit is a user defined function that is used primarily in SQL statements, which might improve its performance.

questions.question_text: Which PRAGMA statement may enable associated PL/SQL functions to run more efficiently when called from SQL?
